results.title: Uber Wants to Rule the World. First It Must Conquer India.
results.abstract: Uber is diving headlong into India, where it must face the sobering realities of analog life in a rapidly developing country.

multimedia.caption: A street in Bangalore, India, as seen by an Uber driver. Uber is pouring money, engineers and logistical expertise into what could be the world’s largest market for transportation services.
multimedia.copyright: Atul Loke for The New York Times

results.title: As New Zealand Courts Tech Talent, Isolation Becomes a Draw
results.abstract: A program to offer developers jobs was flooded with more than 48,000 applications as many in the field look for distance from the political polarization in the United States and Europe.
results.byline: By JACQUELINE WILLIAMS and DAVID STREITFELD

results.title: Apple Gets Permit to Test Self-Driving Cars in California
results.abstract: The permit is the clearest signal yet that the company wants to enter an intensely competitive sector by designing or building autonomous vehicle technology.

multimedia.caption: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has been coy about the company’s self-driving car project, known internally as Project Titan.

results.title: Amid Questions Over Its Culture, Uber Says Its Bookings Doubled in 2016
results.abstract: The ride-hailing service said gross bookings rose to $20 billion in 2016, double the amount in 2015, and net revenue totaled $6.5 billion.

results.title: Robert Taylor, Innovator Who Shaped Modern Computing, Dies at 85
results.abstract: Mr. Taylor’s work was instrumental in the creation of the internet, the modern personal computer and the mouse.

results.title: Tech Roundup: New Zealand Looks Globally to Build Up Its Technology Industry
results.abstract: The South Pacific nation has recently been running a municipal program to lure more coders and engineers from the United States and around the world.

results.title: Tracking the Ticker on the Go
results.abstract: You can customize the information the Google app shows you, including the stocks you want to follow and other news that interests you.

results.title: G.M. Expands Self-Driving Car Operations in Silicon Valley
results.abstract: Traditional automakers are building a greater presence in California to compete with tech companies that are so far leading the pack.

multimedia.caption: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, is seeking to expand and accelerate the company’s development of self-driving cars.

results.title: Social Media Is Not Contributing Significantly to Political Polarization, Paper Says
results.abstract: Researchers at Brown and Stanford Universities found that the growth in political polarization was most significant among the people least likely to be online.

multimedia.caption: The K&N Cafe in Ambridge, Pa., the day after the 2016 presidential election. Americans have become increasingly politically polarized, but social media may not be the defining factor.

results.title: New Tools Needed to Track Technology’s Impact on Jobs, Panel Says
results.abstract: The nation is “flying blind” into a new era of automation and artificial intelligence, the authors of a National Academies study warned.
org_facet: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

multimedia.caption: Automation fears have stirred many fanciful visions of the future. An expert panel calls for new tools of analysis to help workers adapt.
Automation fears have stirred many fanciful visions of the future. An expert panel calls for new tools of analysis to help workers adapt.

results.title: Tech Roundup: Paying Up to $500 to Chat With a Live Streamer
results.abstract: YouTube’s Super Chat feature gives creators on the video site a new way to make money by charging audience members to have their comments highlighted during live streams.

results.title: Send Some Sass With That Text Message
results.abstract: Apple’s own texting app for iOS 10 includes easy ways to liven up your interactions with other iMessage users.

results.title: A Chat With a Live Streamer Is Yours, for a Price
results.abstract: Dedicated video streaming platforms like YouTube and Twitch are looking for ways to sweeten the deal for streamers so they produce more live content.

results.abstract: In the last three months, several high-ranking managers have left the ride-hailing company. At least one has been openly critical about the way the company has been run.

results.title: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation
results.abstract: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.

multimedia.caption: An ocellated lizard. Their scales change from brown and white to black and green as they get older, and scientists say they appear to follow a pattern that is similar to a computer simulation.

results.title: Tech Roundup: Advances for Airlines Aren’t Helping Customer Service
results.abstract: Online check-ins, airport kiosks and the like are divorcing travelers from human workers, with the effort to drag a passenger off a United Airlines flight the culmination.

results.title: Reading E-Books on a Bigger Screen
results.abstract: If you dislike reading on a phone or tablet, you can likely read your electronic books and magazines on your computer’s display instead.

results.title: Burger King ‘O.K. Google’ Ad Doesn’t Seem O.K. With Google
results.abstract: The commercial was a novel but potentially invasive marketing tactic that came as more Americans use voice-activated devices.

results.title: How Technology Has Failed to Improve Your Airline Experience
results.abstract: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.

multimedia.caption: United Airlines planes at San Francisco International Airport. Oscar Munoz, United’s chief executive, offered an apology and pledged to review the airline’s policies two days after a passenger was violently ejected from an overbooked flight.

results.title: Imagining the Retail Store of the Future
results.abstract: Will it have robots? No checkout counters? Virtual fitting rooms? Almost anything seems possible.

results.title: Tesla’s Market Surge Has Even Fans Looking for Feet of Clay
results.abstract: Investors have been energized by the electric-car maker’s upbeat outlook for delivering its mass-market model. Now its chief, Elon Musk, must deliver.

results.title: Border Officers Nearly Double Searches of Electronic Devices, U.S. Says
results.abstract: There were nearly 15,000 searches at border crossings and airports from October to March — up from 8,383 a year before, Customs and Border Protection said.

results.title: Tech Roundup: The Vast Criminal Enterprise Lurking Behind Spam Emails
results.abstract: The Department of Justice accused a Russian of being a mastermind behind an enormous spam email operation that officials said drained people’s bank accounts.

results.title: Yahoo Is Sued Over $17 Million Fund for Chinese Dissidents
results.abstract: Activists said the company failed to properly oversee the fund it created to help Chinese writers, democracy advocates and human rights lawyers persecuted for standing up to the country’s government.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Harry Wu in 2011. A lawsuit against Yahoo says that Mr. Wu, who died last year, misspent money set aside for a foundation that Yahoo created to aid Chinese dissidents.

results.title: A Hangout for Old Desktop Notifications
results.abstract: If the pop-up alerts that bring you news and information from your Mac’s apps disappear before you can read them, check the Notifications Center.

results.title: Deal by Chinese Tech Company LeEco for Vizio Dies
results.abstract: The ambitious conglomerate, which said unspecified regulatory problems had derailed the American TV acquisition, grew quickly but its cash has dwindled.

multimedia.caption: LeEco, which has investments in products from telephones to cars, said it would not buy the American television maker Vizio.

results.title: Toshiba Casts Doubt on Its Ability to Stay in Business
results.abstract: Struggling after a disastrous foray into nuclear power, the company hopes a sale of part of its microchip business, its crown jewel, could alleviate uncertainty.
results.byline: By JONATHAN SOBLE and PAUL MOZUR

multimedia.caption: One of the better-known suitors for Toshiba’s chip unit is Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn.

results.title: New Technology Is Built on a ‘Stack.’ Is That the Best Way to Understand Everything Else, Too?
results.abstract: People from nutrition geeks to philosophers are using a metaphor from software to describe the world.

results.title: That Fingerprint Sensor on Your Phone Is Not as Safe as You Think
results.abstract: New research suggests that the fingerprint security features on iPhones and Android devices can be easily fooled by so-called MasterPrint fakes.

multimedia.caption: Nasir Memon, a professor of computer science and engineering at New York University, said his research into master fingerprints suggested that the security on iPhones and Android phones could be easily cracked.
multimedia.copyright: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

results.title: U.S. Accuses Russian Email Spammer of Vast Network of Fraud
results.abstract: Peter Levashov, 36, arrested on vacation in Spain, is charged with wire fraud and unauthorized interception of electronic communications.

multimedia.caption: President Trump boarded Air Force One on Sunday. The Justice Department’s accusations against a Russian email spammer are sure to raise tensions when Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson visits Moscow this week.

results.title: Tech Roundup: Canada Spends to Keep A.I. Experts Home
results.abstract: Canadian researchers have played a major role in developing artificial intelligence. Now the government is helping to create research centers to retain them.

results.title: Yes, Another Windows 10 Update Is Here
results.abstract: Microsoft is now rolling out the Windows 10 Creators Update, a new version of its flagship operating system.

results.title: Tesla Hits a New Milestone, Passing G.M. in Valuation
results.abstract: After passing Ford Motor a week ago, the electric car company edged past General Motors in early trading, with a market capitalization of $50.9 billion.

results.title: Spain Arrests Russian Thought to Be Kingpin of Computer Spam
results.abstract: Western cybersecurity researchers have identified the man being held, Peter Levashov, as the spammer known as Peter Severa, though some doubt he is the same person.
